author: By Robert Leonard and Matt Russell
title: Why Rural America Needs Immigrants
description: We need smart policy like immigration reform for sustained growth.
content: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — Rural America has a growth problem. Business and industry desperately need workers, but the domestic labor pool is shallow, and the nation’s birthrate is slowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Alex Rodriguez Joins Ownership Group for Timberwolves and Lynx
description: Rodriguez and Marc Lore, an e-commerce billionaire, have a pathway to controlling ownership of the professional Minnesota basketball teams in two years.
content: Alex Rodriguez, the former Yankees star, and Marc Lore, an e-commerce billionaire, officially joined the ownership group of the N.B.A.’s Minnesota Timberwolves and the W.N.B.A.’s Minnesota Lynx on Wednesday, after their purchase of a limited stake in the teams was approved by the N.B.A.’s Board of Governors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Man Pleads Guilty to Murder in Deadly Shooting at California Synagogue
description: In a plea deal that spared him the death penalty, John T. Earnest admitted to killing a woman and injuring three others at a synagogue on the last day of Passover in 2019.
content: A 22-year-old man pleaded guilty on Tuesday to murder in a deadly attack at a synagogue in Southern California on the last day of Passover two years ago, during which he spewed anti-Semitic remarks, fatally shot a 60-year-old woman and injured three others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik, Vjosa Isai and Maria Abi-Habib
title: The U.S. reaffirms its land border restrictions as Canada relaxes its own. Mexico has none.
description: U.S. politicians from both parties have pressed for reopening, along with residents of Canada and Mexico.
content: The United States will keep its land borders with Mexico and Canada closed for all nonessential travel for at least another month, the Department of Homeland Security said on Wednesday, extending the travel restrictions just days after Canadian officials announced they would soon reopen to U.S. travelers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J.S. Marcus
title: After 145 Years, Bayreuth Festival Has Its First Female Conductor
description: Oksana Lyniv will open the festival, founded by Wagner to present his own operas, leading “Der Fliegende Holländer.”
content: The Bayreuth Festival in Germany is one of the most venerable events in classical music. Richard Wagner founded it to present his own operas, and it’s been open most summers since 1876.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard H. Pildes
title: America Has Too Many Elections
description: The two-year House term has profound consequences for our government  — and too many of them are negative.
content: The ability of the American political system to deliver major policies on urgent issues is hampered by features of our institutions that we take for granted and rarely think about. Take the Constitution’s requirement that House members serve for only two-year terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Lyft will team up with Ford and a self-driving car start-up to offer rides in Miami.
description: The companies plan to begin offering the service this year, expanding later to Austin, Texas. A human will still be behind the wheel.
content: Ford Motor and its autonomous-driving affiliate, Argo AI, have formed an alliance with Lyft in an effort to begin offering rides in self-driving cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: A Treasury official says an international tax deal would help make globalization work.
description: He suggested that a lack of clarity and consensus in the international system could end up hurting cross-border investment.
content: The Biden administration made its case on Wednesday for why multinational corporations should support an international tax agreement aimed at cracking down on tax shelters, with a top official arguing that the deal would restore order to globalization and blunt the forces of protectionism and populism that have posed a threat to business in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: The Helpful Hand Guiding Brisbane’s Olympic Victory
description: John Coates may be the most influential figure in the Olympic movement after I.O.C. President Thomas Bach. Critics of Coates say he has too much power.
content: TOKYO — For the man who wrote the rules, the outcome could not have been more satisfying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caragh Poh
title: ‘Was the Astor Place Kmart Haunted?’ and Other Thoughts on Its Closing
description: The big-box department store received an unexpected volume of tributes after it abruptly closed in July.
content: Kmart opened its doors at 770 Broadway, a commercial landmark where the West Village meets the East, in 1996. Anyone who’s taken the 6 to Astor Place might recall the big red “K” that can be seen from the Subway platform, beckoning riders to hunt for discounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Wild Guess
description: Alex Vratsanos shows some pizazz.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes when you’re solving, you just have to take a wild guess. When a puzzle has two stacks of 15-letter entries, wild guesses can make the difference between breaking into a puzzle and staring at the screen or newspaper, helplessly unable to move forward. Taking a wild guess can also be a fun little game to play with yourself, not unlike guessing the Final Jeopardy question based on just the category before the commercial break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Skipping the Olympics Is ‘Not an Option’ for Many Advertisers
description: Companies have spent more than $1 billion on ads timed to the Tokyo Games, which will take place in empty arenas as the pandemic lingers.
content: The Olympics have long been an almost ideal forum for companies looking to promote themselves, with plenty of opportunities for brands to nestle ads among the pageantry and feel-good stories about athletes overcoming adversity — all for less than the price of a Super Bowl commercial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: American Ballet Theater to Return to Lincoln Center in October
description: The full-length ballet “Giselle” will open the company’s season at the David H. Koch Theater Oct. 20.
content: American Ballet Theater will return to Lincoln Center for indoor performances in October, the company said Wednesday. Its homecoming season at the David H. Koch Theater is set to feature the world premiere of the work “ZigZag” by Jessica Lang and the stage debut of pieces by Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Rudd that were first shown online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: We Need to Know How Menopause Changes Women’s Brains
description: This might turn out to be a crucial window to try to prevent Alzheimer’s and other chronic diseases that often accompany older age.
content: During menopause, which marks the end of a woman’s menstrual cycles, her ovaries stop producing the hormones estrogen and progesterone, bringing an end to her natural childbearing years. But those hormones also regulate how the brain functions, and the brain governs their release — meaning that menopause is a neurological process as well. “Many of the symptoms of menopause cannot possibly be directly produced by the ovaries, if you think about the hot flashes, the night sweats, the anxiety, the depression, the insomnia, the brain fog,” says Lisa Mosconi, an associate professor of neurology at Weill Cornell Medicine and director of its Women’s Brain Initiative. “Those are brain symptoms, and we should look at the brain as something that is impacted by menopause at least as much as your ovaries are.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Cumming
title: The Taste of Summer, Now in Canned Form
description: A new wave of independent beverage brands, some promising health benefits and others a good old-fashioned buzz, are remaking the way we unwind.
content: In Cormac McCarthy’s 2006 novel, “The Road,” which is set in a desolate postapocalyptic America, the protagonist finds a can of Coke and offers it to his son. Sweet and fizzy, the soda is a taste of the lost world, preserved against the odds. The world’s flora and fauna might have died off, the human population reduced to refugees and cannibals, but the can is intact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Brilliance, and Heartbreak: The Story of Chris Paul’s Career
description: Paul, the veteran Phoenix Suns point guard, ends this N.B.A. season the same way he has 15 times before: without a championship. The question is whether that should define him.
content: In defeat, Devin Booker said that the youthful Phoenix Suns had hoped to skip many of the brutal roadblocks that can quickly vanquish a team with championship aspirations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: Loving Across Borders
description: Through citizenship insecurities and pandemic separations, here’s how three couples managed to stay together.
content: At age 11, Julissa Arce came to the United States on a visa that expired three years later. For more than a decade, she lived as an undocumented immigrant, fearful of revealing her secret to anyone. “Every phone call or email I got from human resources would make my blood run cold,” she wrote in her Modern Love essay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Djinis
title: ‘It’s gross’: A summer of red tides piles up 600 tons of dead fish on Florida beaches.
description: “This,” proclaimed an editorial in The Tampa Bay Times last week, “is what climate change smells like.”
content: COQUINA BEACH, Fla. — The stench hits first, uncomfortable at best and gag-inducing at worst. Then comes a small tickle in the back of the throat that won’t go away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Sophie Kasakove and Daniel Victor
title: U.S. Life Expectancy Plunged in 2020, Especially for Black and Hispanic Americans
description: The 18-month drop, the steepest decline since World War II, was fueled by the coronavirus pandemic.
content: New federal data draws one of the starkest illustrations to date of how the coronavirus pandemic has disproportionately affected Hispanic and Black Americans, showing that they suffered a far steeper drop in life expectancy in 2020 than white Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Markham
title: The Man Who Filed More Than 180 Disability Lawsuits
description: Is it profiteering — or justice?
content: DanVy Vu was out on the floor of her restaurant one chilly evening in December 2019 when a staff member called her to the hostess station to assist an angry customer — a man in a wheelchair who, along with his wife, had been stuck outside. The couple said that they had tried the accessible entrance through a courtyard but found the gate locked, which had left the man shivering out in the cold while his wife circled back to a nonaccessible entrance at the front of the restaurant for help opening the gate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: More than 30 former top Senate Democratic aides call for changes to the filibuster rules.
description: Ex-chiefs of staff say the Senate rules need to be changed to end what they called abuse of the tactic.
content: Hoping to build momentum for a change in Senate filibuster rules, more than 30 former chiefs of staff to Democratic senators have written an open letter calling for “repeal or reform” of the procedural tactic they say no longer serves its original purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Night of the Kings,’ ‘Lucky’ and More Streaming Gems
description: Find something off the beaten path to fill those summer nights at home.
content: It’s not just summer blockbuster season at the reopened multiplexes; the streamers are going big as well, with mega-productions like “The Tomorrow War” and “Fear Street” dominating ad space and home pages. But if those aren’t your cup of tea, no worries — we’ve got a handful of American indies, foreign flicks and thoughtful documentaries to fill your summer nights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: This Butterfly Was the First in North America That People Made Extinct
description: New research suggests the iconic Xerces blue butterfly may have been its own species.
content: More than a century ago, a bluish butterfly flitted among the sand dunes of the Sunset District in San Francisco and laid its eggs on a plant known as deerweed. As the city’s development overtook the dunes and deerweed, the butterflies vanished, too. The last Xerces blue butterfly was collected in 1941 from Lobos Creek by an entomologist who would later lament that he had killed what was one of the last living members of the species.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: In ‘Xiao Wu,’ a Wandering Pickpocket in the People’s China
description: Jia Zhangke’s debut feature, released in the United States in 1999 and newly restored, follows a nowhere man around his nowhere city in China.
content: Made for a pittance with nonprofessional actors, officially unapproved in China and first shown in the United States in 1999, Jia Zhangke’s debut feature “Xiao Wu” depicted a deadbeat Chinese protagonist and a backwater milieu few Westerners had ever seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Farrell
title: How to Host a Relaxed Breton-Style Summer Lunch
description: Benoît Rauzy and Anthony Watson, the founders of the design studio Atelier Vime, celebrated a long-awaited reunion with friends at their home in the French countryside.
content: In a secluded hamlet near Audierne in northwestern France, with grounds that slope gently down to the Goyen River, sits the late 18th-century Breton farmhouse of Benoît Rauzy and Anthony Watson. Though raised in Paris, Rauzy has spent vacations in this windswept corner of Brittany ever since his parents bought the whitewashed, blue-shuttered house — and the surrounding two acres of meadow, orchards and sheltered gardens — in the 1960s. The salty air that blows through the property is still scented by the roses and hydrangeas Rauzy’s father, Jacques, planted there more than 40 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Clearview AI raises $30 million from investors despite legal troubles.
description: The facial-recognition start-up closed a Series B financing round. It faces multiple lawsuits challenging its business model.
content: Clearview AI is currently the target of multiple class-action lawsuits and a joint investigation by Britain and Australia. That hasn’t kept investors away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather and Alexandra E. Petri
title: What to watch: Softball continues and men’s soccer begins.
description: Another day of sports continues with softball and men’s soccer games.
content: TOKYO — It’s Thursday at the Olympic Games, or as it is officially known, “Day Negative 1.” (The opening ceremony is on Friday.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: A top political prisoner dies of Covid in Myanmar, with others in critical condition.
description: The death of U Nyan Win, a lawyer for Aung San Suu Kyi who was locked up for months after a February coup, pointed to the growing toll of Myanmar’s outbreak.
content: U Nyan Win, a spokesman for the governing party of Myanmar that was ousted by the military earlier this year, died on Tuesday of Covid-19 contracted in prison, his lawyer said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Britain Introduces Measures to Curb Street Harassment and Violence Against Women
description: The proposals come months after Sarah Everard, a 33-year-old marketing executive, was raped and murdered. She disappeared as she walked home from a friend’s house in South London.
content: LONDON — The British government on Wednesday unveiled proposals to curb the harassment of women on the streets, part of a wider crackdown on violence that comes months after a national outcry over the murder of Sarah Everard, who was abducted while walking home this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Battle for Power in Haiti Extends to Lobbying in Washington
description: Rival political figures and interests are doling out big sums to the influence industry to win support from the United States even as problems in Haiti remain unsolved.
content: WASHINGTON — The struggle for power in Haiti after the assassination of the country’s president has spilled onto K Street, where rival Haitian politicians, business leaders and interest groups are turning to lobbyists to wage an expensive and escalating proxy battle for influence with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: Jeff Bezos vows to fight climate change, but space tourism could do more harm, critics say.
description: Mr. Bezos says space tourism is a first step toward moving people (and heavy industry) into space to avert an energy crisis on Earth.
content: Upon descending from his trip to the edge of space on Tuesday, Jeff Bezos, the richest person on the planet, reaffirmed his commitment to fight climate change. “We have to build a road to space so that our kids and their kids can build a future,” he told MSNBC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: For the First Time, an American Will Run the American Bar in London
description: The storied cocktail bar, which opened in the 1890s at the Savoy Hotel, has named Shannon Tebay of Death & Co. in New York as its new head bartender.
content: For the first time in its history, an American will run the American Bar at the Savoy Hotel in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Crews saved a World War II memorial from the Bootleg Fire.
description: The Mitchell Memorial commemorates the deaths of six people in Oregon who were killed by a Japanese bomb.
content: Firefighters assigned to battle the Bootleg Fire in southwestern Oregon last week helped save a memorial at the site of the only casualties in the contiguous United States from direct enemy action during World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why Aren’t the Vaccines Approved?
description: The F.D.A. is encouraging people to get a Covid-19 shot — but hasn’t formally approved those vaccines.
content: It is the most discordant part of the U.S. government’s response to Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Chip shortages force German carmakers to throttle production even as demand recovers.
description: BMW’s production fell short by 10,000 vehicles for the week, and Daimler had to briefly stop assembly lines at a plant in Germany.
content: The global semiconductor shortage is disrupting production in the German car industry just as demand rebounds strongly from the pandemic-induced downturn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Federal Judge Blocks Ban on Nearly All Abortions in Arkansas
description: The law would have banned the procedure except to save the life of a pregnant woman in a medical emergency.
content: A federal judge on Tuesday temporarily blocked Arkansas from enforcing a strict new law that would ban nearly all abortions, a decision that comes as many states with Republican-controlled legislatures are trying to force the issue before a newly reshaped Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John F. Wasik
title: Workers’ Financial Stress Is Rising. Can Corporate Programs Help?
description: More and more, larger employers are offering “wellness” programs that can coach people to better manage their money, combining digital tools and a human touch.
content: Soni Kapoor wanted to stay ahead of the game on his personal finances and retirement planning. As the product marketing manager for the Silicon Valley tech firm Synopsys, Mr. Kapoor kept meticulous entries of his expenses and investments in a personal spreadsheet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das and Victor Mather
title: The U.S. and Japanese softball teams open with victories to start off the Games.
description: The U.S. held off Italy, while the host country beat Australia under the mercy rule.
content: TOKYO — The U.S. softball team, behind the pitching of the ageless Cat Osterman, defeated a tenacious Italy team, 2-0, as softball returned to the Olympics on Wednesday for the first time since 2008.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Shorter Hours, No Promotions: How the Pandemic Stalled Some Parents’ Careers
description: The disruption to child care could have long-term career costs, and the ones likeliest to pay are mothers.
content: Millions of parents, mostly mothers, have stopped working for pay because of the pandemic child care crisis. But for many more who have held on to their jobs, child care demands have also affected their careers, often in less visible ways. They have worked fewer hours, declined assignments or decided not to take a promotion or pursue a new job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Is N.Y.C. Doing Enough to Slow 3rd Virus Wave? Experts Raise Doubts.
description: On Wednesday, the city announced that all public hospital employees must be vaccinated or face weekly coronavirus testing.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Wednesday that some city employees who aren’t vaccinated will soon be required to get a weekly coronavirus test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German Candidates Fail to Find Footing in Flood Response
description: So far, none of the main contenders to replace Angela Merkel have come across as strong leaders in the aftermath of floods that killed 170 people and caused billions in damages.
content: BERLIN — Floods have had a way of reshaping German politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Solomon
title: Exploring Seattle’s Booming Beer Scene
description: This northwestern city makes some of the most creative craft beers around. The best place to try them is in the Ballard Brewery District.
content: Seattle is home to nearly 70 breweries — a staggering number, greater than several states can boast. Summer is one of the best times to backstroke through this ocean of cool beer as the pandemic loosens its grip. There’s always something new to try and someplace new to go as breweries continue to take root in this thirsty city, sometimes in the unlikeliest of places. Ersatz biergartens have sprung up in parking lots as the pandemic forces breweries to become creative about how to gather people safely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Kodak Deletes Post by Photographer Who Called Xinjiang an ‘Orwellian Dystopia’
description: After public backlash in China, the American company dropped an Instagram post featuring images of a region where accusations of human rights violations have drawn intense scrutiny.
content: The American company Eastman Kodak has deleted an Instagram post featuring images of Xinjiang, a western Chinese region where the government is accused of grave human rights violations, after an online backlash from Beijing’s supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Analysis: Enacting policy through spending may help Biden avoid a political minefield.
description: The 2020 Democratic presidential primary was often described as a contest over whether the country needed a return to normalcy or sweeping change.
content: The 2020 Democratic presidential primary was often described as a contest over whether the country needed a return to normalcy or sweeping change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1946: British Bakeries Sell Out Before Bread Rationing Begins
description: Britain rationed many foodstuffs during World War II, but extended rationing to bread only in the lean years immediately after. Bread remained rationed until 1948, and some food rationing continued until 1954.
content: From the Herald Tribune Bureau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: How to Follow the Olympics.
description: Starting now.
content: Welcome. The opening ceremony isn’t until Friday, but the Tokyo Olympics are already underway, and even if you’re questioning the utility of such a spectacle in the shadow of a pandemic, there are likely events you’re excited to watch, athletes you’re excited to root for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $1.5 Million Homes in Illinois, Michigan and California
description: A brick Colonial Revival house in Highland Park, a 1935 vacation cottage in Grand Haven and a contemporary home in Oakland.
content: This North Shore suburban house originally belonged to Leslie Goudie, a leader of the Chicago Teamsters union at a time when the organization was rocked by gangland violence. Mr. Goudie was reported to have traveled in an armored car in the company of police bodyguards to avoid the fate of his predecessor, Patrick Berrell, who was killed by machine-gun fire. Mr. Goudie died in 1944 of complications from hernia surgery. There has been only one owner of the home since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Drug Distributors and J.&J. Reach $26 Billion Deal to End Opioids Lawsuits
description: The agreement would allow funds to begin flowing from the companies to states and communities to pay for addiction and prevention services.
content: After nearly two years of wrangling, the country’s three major drug distributors and a pharmaceutical giant have reached a $26 billion deal with states that would release some of the biggest companies in the industry from all legal liability in the opioid epidemic, a decades-long public health crisis that has killed hundreds of thousands of Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reacting to Chinese Cyberattacks
description: Why does the U.S. treat hacking by Beijing differently from infiltrations by other foreign actors?
content: Soon after the United States discovered a major hacking of SolarWinds by Russia, another one was discovered, this time carried out by the main Chinese intelligence agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadja Popovich and Josh Katz
title: Wildfire smoke spreads haze and health warnings to East Coast.
description: Smoke from blazes in the Western United States and Canada stretched across North America this week.
content: Wildfire smoke from Canada and the Western United States stretched across North America this week, covering skies in a thick haze, tinting the sun a malevolent red and triggering health alerts from Toronto to Philadelphia. Air quality remained in the unhealthy range across much of the East Coast on Wednesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: A Hot Fitness Trend Among Olympians: Blood Flow Restriction
description: Some athletes in Tokyo are indulging in a trendy technique to enhance the effects of training and stimulate recovery. Credit a Japanese former power lifter.
content: Every four years, the Summer Olympics shows the world the latest training or recovery method the greatest athletes have taken up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: The Spanish swimmer Ona Carbonell says she is disappointed to leave her breastfeeding son at home.
description: Carbonell, competing in her third Games, said in an Instagram video that she had been made to choose between her family and her Olympic goal.
content: The Spanish artistic swimmer Ona Carbonell is expressing her “disappointment and disillusionment” that it is not practical to bring her son to Japan for the Tokyo Olympics while she is breastfeeding him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Climate Change Comes for Rich Countries
description: Brutal heat and deadly floods show a world unprepared to cope with extreme weather.
content: I wrote an article over the weekend about the rich world facing extreme weather disasters intensified by climate change. Since then, the skies over New York City, where I live, turned an ominous shade of red because of smoke from wildfires on the other side of the continent. One fire, the Bootleg, was messing with the weather out West. British Columbia declared a state of emergency as wildfires prompted evacuation orders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: ‘I Am Thirsty!’ Water Shortages Compound Iran’s Problems
description: A prolonged drought worsened by climate change and government mismanagement has added a volatile new element to the swirl of challenges in Iran, ranging from the pandemic to U.S. sanctions.
content: Iran is struggling with a fifth wave of the coronavirus pandemic, an economy strained by American sanctions and stalled talks on rescuing a nuclear agreement that was once seen as an economic salvation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Meet the Water Witches of California
description: Wednesday: The demand for nonscientific water-finding services shows the desperation of farmers during a deepening drought.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Among Mormon Women, Frank Talk About Sacred Underclothes
description: Frustrated by itchy, constrictive church-designed garments, they are asking for better fit, more options and “buttery soft fabric.”
content: Sasha Piton was on a hike near her home in Idaho Falls, Idaho, when she realized something was wrong. The trek was just a few miles, and not strenuous, but a rash was spreading along the crease above her thigh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Brisbane is awarded the 2032 Summer Games.
description: The city in Australia won the first bid for a Summer Games under a new process by the International Olympic Committee meant to discourage bidding wars.
content: TOKYO — As the Summer Olympics stumbled to an unsteady start on Wednesday, the International Olympic Committee took a big step toward crystallizing its long-term future by voting to officially select Brisbane, Australia, as host of the Summer Games in 2032.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: ‘Incel’ Is Charged With Plotting to Shoot Women, U.S. Says
description: Tres Genco, 21, of Hillsboro, Ohio, was charged with an attempted hate crime and illegally possessing a machine gun, federal prosecutors said.
content: An Ohio man who was part of an online community of “incels,” or misogynists who blame women for denying them what they believe is their right to sexual intercourse, was arrested on Wednesday and charged with plotting to shoot students in sororities, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isadora Kosofsky
title: Up Close, the Suffering and Hope in a Desperate Covid Fight
description: After documenting a last-resort treatment at one hospital, a photographer who spent hours in patients’ rooms describes capturing the humanity of the struggle.
content: As I photographed people in Covid-19 intensive care units early this year, I was protected by four sets of plastic: glasses, goggles, face shield and viewfinder. But there is no protection for the pain one takes in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Sends Up ‘Space Cowboy’ Jeff Bezos
description: Stephen Colbert joked that the Amazon billionaire came back from space “extra divorced.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A flood disaster in China.
content: At least 25 people died in and around Zhengzhou, a city of five million and the capital of Henan Province, when the heaviest rainfall on record caused severe flooding. Twelve of the victims were stuck on a subway train when waters rose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 15 Easy Recipes for Ripe, In-Season Tomatoes
description: Let the indisputable star of the summer shine in any one of these delicious dishes.
content: Perhaps you’ve already excitedly made gazpacho and pico de gallo and maybe even prepared a batch of red sauce for the freezer, but those perfectly ripe (and fresh) summer tomatoes at the market sure are tempting. So you lug home another few pounds of them, unable to resist but without a plan. Good news: New York Times Cooking has plenty. Below are more than a dozen recipes that put the quintessential fruit of the season front and center, so you won’t have regretted following their call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: We Are Leaving ‘Lost Einsteins’ Behind
description: Hundreds of thousands of highly capable people are being dropped by the wayside.
content: In the international competition to produce a work force equipped to cope with accelerating rates of technological innovation, the United States is leaving hundreds of thousands of highly capable people by the wayside, perhaps even millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saul Austerlitz
title: ‘The Daily Show’ at 25: The Creators Look Back
description: The Comedy Central stalwart debuted in July 1996. The creators Madeleine Smithberg and Lizz Winstead reflect on the early days, when “Dateline” was a main target and Jon Stewart took over from Craig Kilborn.
content: And now for your moment of Zen: “The Daily Show” turns 25 years old on Thursday. The scrappy news spoof that debuted on a second-tier cable network has since become a staple of late-night television, a nearly unmatched comedy launchpad and a satirical extension of the thing it was created to mock: the TV news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Canadian province declares a state of emergency, evacuating thousands.
description: Nearly 300 fires in British Columbia have prompted evacuation orders affecting more than 5,700 people, officials said.
content: A provincial state of emergency was declared by the government of British Columbia on Tuesday after wildfires across the region prompted dozens of evacuation orders, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Mourning Haitians Console Martine Moïse, Widow of the Slain President
description: The wife of President Jovenel Moïse, who was wounded in the attack that killed her husband, returned to Haiti after getting medical treatment in the U.S.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE — Four days after surprising Haitians by returning to her country in a sling and a bulletproof vest, the widow of Haiti’s assassinated president appeared before her fellow citizens on Wednesday at a memorial to her husband.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: U.S. scrambles to move translators from Afghanistan while leaving many in limbo.
description: This month, 2,500 Afghans will be sent in stages to an Army base in Fort Lee, Va.
content: An additional 4,000 Afghans who worked with American forces, many of them interpreters, had been approved to relocate to the United States with their families in light of the withdrawal of U.S. troops, State Department officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Are You a Bezos?
description: When Jeff Bezos flew off in his rocket, he became the international (interstellar?) symbol of the male in midlife crisis.
content: Perhaps the most noteworthy thing about the whole thing was that it wasn’t that noteworthy at all: another Tuesday. Another billionaire businessman paying to catapult himself into space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. military official says a ‘complete Taliban takeover’ is possible in Afghanistan.
description: The comments by Gen. Mark A. Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, echoed mounting reports from the ground in Afghanistan.
content: The nation’s top military officer offered a glum assessment on Wednesday of the security situation in Afghanistan, saying the Taliban had seized “strategic momentum” over Afghan military forces who were falling back to prioritize the protection of important cities, including Kabul, the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Kathy Andrade, Unionist Who Fought for Immigrant Workers, Dies at 88
description: Her work on behalf of garment workers helped prod organized labor to rethink its approach to an increasingly immigrant-based work force.
content: Kathy Andrade, a longtime garment union activist in New York City and a native of El Salvador who pushed the labor movement to embrace immigrants rather than view them as threatening the livelihoods of American-born workers, died on July 2 in Manhattan. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: With the N.B.A. Finals Complete, Maria Taylor Leaves ESPN
description: The popular studio host and reporter was widely expected to depart after disparaging remarks made by a colleague were made public. Her next stop could be NBC.
content: On Tuesday, she hosted the N.B.A. finals for ESPN. The next day she was gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Is ‘Loki’ a True Marvel Variant? Or Just a Fun Experiment?
description: The latest Disney+ superhero show embraced chaos in its storytelling. Is Marvel willing to do the same within its ever expanding universe of films and TV shows?
content: One thing Marvel knows how to do is expand a story. Think back to the nascent days of the Marvel Cinematic Universe in the early ’00s. The so-called Phase 1 was about building out the superhero roster with individual film narratives that would dovetail into a big crossover movie: “The Avengers.” A decade and a half later, the crossovers are old hat, the Easter eggs are expected, and a spate of new movies and TV shows continue to provide an influx of stories and characters that branch off into their own universes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: How Nations Are Learning to ‘Let It Go’ and Live With Covid
description: More officials are encouraging people to return to their daily rhythms and transition to a new normal. But scientists warn that it may be too soon to design exit strategies for the pandemic.
content: SINGAPORE — England has removed nearly all coronavirus restrictions. Germany is allowing vaccinated people to travel without quarantines. Outdoor mask mandates are mostly gone in Italy. Shopping malls remain open in Singapore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Goodbye, Dolly: With Their Bids, Fans Hold Onto Carol Channing
description: Awards and autographs, costumes and wigs have recently been sold at auction. Even the glamorous red gown from “Hello, Dolly!” found a home.
content: LOS ANGELES — For men of a certain age — and it is mostly men — Carol Channing was something of an obsession. They waited by stage doors from Broadway to Tampa for her to emerge. They devoured the “Hello, Dolly!” cast album as teenagers, watched her on television and in the movies and, at times, dressed up in drag to impersonate her — the exaggerated red lipstick, the drone of a nasal voice, the wide-eyed comedic delivery and the burst of puffy hair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: The U.K. Is Balking at the Northern Ireland Protocol. So, What Is That?
description: Britain has said that the Northern Ireland protocol could create so many problems that it might have to be scrapped. What exactly is it? And why all the fuss?
content: LONDON — First came the shortages on supermarket shelves. Then the “sausage wars” over the supply of chilled meat. Now, the rift over post-Brexit trade rules for Northern Ireland is threatening to become a full-scale confrontation between Britain and the European Union — and one that could upset the United States too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Lauren Hirsch
title: Robinhood’s Guinea Pig for Upending Public Offerings: Itself
description: The stock trading app is opening its initial public offering and investor presentations to everyday investors. The risks are significant.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Vlad Tenev and Baiju Bhatt created the stock trading app Robinhood in 2013, the entrepreneurs declared that their mission was to democratize Wall Street and make finance accessible to all. Now as they prepare to make their company public, they are taking that ethos to a new extreme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Milwaukee Bucks Win the N.B.A. Championship
description: The Bucks defeated the Phoenix Suns in the N.B.A. finals in six games for their first title in 50 years. It’s the first championship for Giannis Antetokounmpo.
content: MILWAUKEE — A half-century ago, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar — a young goliath then known as Lew Alcindor — led the Milwaukee Bucks to their first championship. For decades, it was the only time the franchise had reached that height.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zara Stone
title: The Pandemic Rush on Prison Weddings
description: With Covid-19 restrictions lifted, many inmates who had to postpone their weddings last year are hoping to finally tie the knot. However, the increased demand could mean a longer wait.
content: Like many pandemic brides in 2020, Jenny Smith’s wedding plans were put on hold. She had hoped to reschedule for this summer, but found that her officiant was booked up until February 2022. “I’m impatient to get it done — I’m ready to be his Mrs.,” said Ms. Smith, 41, who lives in Garland, Texas, and is unemployed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Higher Fares on the Subway? Not This Year.
description: Transit officials hold off on  an increase for  the subway, buses and  commuter rail lines to help  riders hurt financially by the pandemic.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Here’s how many nations are learning to live with Covid.
description: SINGAPORE — England has removed nearly all coronavirus restrictions. Germany is allowing vaccinated people to travel without quarantines. Mask mandates are gone in Italy. Shopping malls remain open in Singapore.
content: SINGAPORE — England has removed nearly all coronavirus restrictions. Germany is allowing vaccinated people to travel without quarantines. Mask mandates are gone in Italy. Shopping malls remain open in Singapore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitchell Kuga
title: From Cassi Namoda, a Delectable Anchovy Toast
description: Food has long been intertwined with the artist’s practice, but a simple open-faced sandwich has been her favorite thing to make at her studio this summer.
content: During a four-week residency at Casa Balandra, located in Marratxí about a half-hour drive outside of Palma, Majorca, this spring, Cassi Namoda would take long walks, picking oranges and green almonds along the way. “I might have been trespassing,” she admits. The New York-based artist, whose colorful paintings typically depict scenes of postcolonial Mozambique, where she was born, also found herself drawn to the traditional Spanish ceramic tiles that decorated the facades of nearby buildings and featured historical images and texts — and decided to paint some of her own. “I wanted to be honest to the landscape,” says Namoda, 32. So she acquired a few loose four-by-four-inch tiles from the man who operated the local kiln and, after glazing them with various configurations of conjoined fetuses connected at the neck, torso and belly, using four tiles per image, returned to have them fired. “I think the guy thought I was a little bit absurd,” she says with a laugh. To her, though, the works signaled a rebirth after a long year upended by Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: PG&E Aims to Curb Wildfire Risk by Burying Many Power Lines
description: The California utility said the work would involve about 10,000 miles of its network, a project potentially costing tens of billions of dollars.
content: Pacific Gas & Electric, aiming to show its determination to overcome a history of safety problems, announced Wednesday that it planned to put 10,000 miles of its power lines underground to prevent the kind of wildfires that led the utility to bankruptcy court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Ultra City Smiths’ Review: New York Neo-Noir, With Plastic Dolls
description: The creator of “Patriot” and “Perpetual Grace Ltd.” delivers another show not quite like any other.
content: If you’re looking for something different on television, an exotic bloom amid the endless rows of spider plants, the writer and director Steven Conrad presents an interesting case. His previous series, dark-comic pastiches of the spy thriller (“Patriot”) and the contemporary western (“Perpetual Grace Ltd.”), didn’t feel unfamiliar, both because they’re faithful to their sources and because there are plenty of other high-concept genre workouts on offer. On the other hand, Conrad is a talented and distinctive writer, and his shows have had an idiosyncratic mix of mournful humor and cool absurdism that has set them apart, and inspired a cultish devotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Lobrano
title: Making Discovery, Not Distance, Travel’s Point
description: As a veteran travel writer is reminded on a short jaunt from his home in France, you don’t need to go far to get away. “Small travel,” he finds, has its own rewards.
content: On a morning in mid-May after three months in lockdown, Bruno, my French spouse, and I made our escape from Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Accepting the virus.
content: Governments across the world are moving away from a cautious approach and instead encouraging people to transition to the new normal, and return en masse to subways, offices and restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Scents and Science Mingle in ‘The Joy of Sweat’
description: In her illuminating new book, Sarah Everts offers a guide to the necessity and virtues of perspiration.
content: In “The Joy of Sweat,” an entertaining and illuminating guide to the necessity and virtues of perspiration, the science journalist Sarah Everts points out that plenty of people pay good money to exude sweat while also paying good money to hide it. Saunas, spin classes and hot yoga, yes; but also deodorant, dress shields and antiperspirants that deliberately create what Everts calls (vividly and unappetizingly) a “sweat-pore plug.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Another Big Tech Critic Joins Biden’s Antitrust Team
description: Jonathan Kanter will lead the Justice Department’s trustbusting unit.
content: After six months and much speculation, the White House has finally nominated someone to lead the antitrust division at the Justice Department: Jonathan Kanter, the former Paul Weiss lawyer and longtime critic of Big Tech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Olympics Virus Cases Raise Tricky Questions About Testing
description: Frequent screening of healthy, vaccinated people will pick up even the mildest infections. How much testing is too much?
content: On Sunday, officials announced that two players on South Africa’s soccer team had become the first athletes to test positive for the coronavirus inside Tokyo’s Olympic Village. The next day, news broke that an alternate on the American women’s gymnastics team, training outside of Tokyo, tested positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: John Mayer’s Empty 1980s Excess
description: “Sob Rock,” an album bloated with signifiers but light on hooks, uses the idea of nostalgia to sell new collectibles from John Mayer, the brand.
content: Right off the top, it needs to be said: great merch. Beautiful merch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Hamilton
title: A Salad So Good You Can Eat It for Breakfast
description: This riff on a classic chef’s salad has a bit of everything in each bite.
content: I remember meeting the father of one of the world’s most admired chefs. Together he and his son, as partners, ran one of the city’s most revered restaurants of the 2000s. The place was an ambitious stateside pioneer of the cuisine that was ripping through Spain at the time, with sensational applications of dehydration, spherification and other chemical and molecular alterations. The dad, a jolly type and freehanded with his affection, had slipped into Prune one night, on the late side, with his gal. And once happily at his table, he feasted mightily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: No, but Really. Should We Contact Aliens?
description: To reach out, or not to reach out: That is the extraterrestrial question.
content: With the U.S. government puzzling over U.F.O.s, and potentially habitable exoplanets in our telescopes, earthlings are closer than ever to finding other intelligent life in the universe. So the existential question is: Should we try to communicate with whatever we think might be out there?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Over 115 Lesson Plans Based on New York Times Articles
description: From the physics of throwing spiral football passes to the secrets of creating a successful podcast, we present a selection of evergreen Lessons of the Day from the 2020-21 school year to help students better understand world events and draw connections to their own lives.
content: Every school day we choose an important or interesting New York Times article to feature in our Lesson of the Day and pair it with a warm-up, critical-thinking questions and a going-further activity. The activities and questions are designed to help students understand the article, contextualize it within current and historical events, and connect it to their own lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: Maine Will Make Companies Pay for Recycling. Here’s How It Works.
description: The law aims to take the cost burden of recycling away from taxpayers. One environmental advocate said the change could be “transformative.”
content: Recycling, that feel-good moment when people put their paper and plastic in special bins, was a headache for municipal governments even in good times. And, only a small amount was actually getting recycled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in London: A 17th-Century Church Tower With Updates
description: The British housing market that emerged from the initial pandemic lockdown is the strongest in years, though London is lagging.
content: This three-bedroom home is a converted 17th-century church tower near Fleet Street, in the heart of London. Designed by the acclaimed architect Sir Christopher Wren, the church was built in 1687 to replace an earlier Medieval church that was destroyed in London’s great fire of 1666; the steeple, made from Portland stone, was added in 1704.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: A 22-year-old was arrested in hacks of Twitter, TikTok and Snapchat.
description: The suspect, Joseph O’Connor, was found in Spain and faces U.S. charges of hacking, extortion and cyberstalking.
content: A 22-year-old man was arrested in Spain on Wednesday in connection with the hack of more than 100 Twitter accounts last July, becoming the fourth person charged in the incident, which led to a temporary shutdown of the social media service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Skipping the Olympics is ‘not an option’ for many advertisers.
description: The Olympics have long been an almost ideal forum for companies promoting themselves, with plenty of opportunities to nestle ads among the pageantry and the feel-good stories about athletes overcoming adversity.
content: The Olympics have long been an almost ideal forum for companies promoting themselves, with plenty of opportunities to nestle ads among the pageantry and the feel-good stories about athletes overcoming adversity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Pfizer will turn to a plant in Africa to help supply the continent with vaccines next year.
description: The deal, which only involves the final stages of manufacturing, falls short of the technology transfer that public health activists have called for.
content: Pfizer and BioNTech said on Wednesday that they have reached an agreement with a South African vaccine manufacturer, starting next year,  to handle the final stages of manufacturing for doses of their Covid shot that will be supplied exclusively to African nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Want to Buy a PlayStation 5? Befriend a Bot.
description: In a pandemic-induced era of scarcity, a bit of automation can go a long way to obtaining the unobtainable.
content: Bots have a bad rep. Shady manipulators have used these automated computer programs on social networks to spread conspiracy theories, spew vitriol and scam people. But when bots are programmed to do good, they can help us accomplish the seemingly impossible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Jamison
title: A Personal History of the C-Section
description: When my daughter’s delivery went off the script I had imagined, it made me wonder about what we ask from our birth stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Judge Temporarily Blocks Arkansas Ban on Health Treatments for Transgender Youth
description: The decision came in response to an American Civil Liberties Union challenge to a first-in-the-nation law enacted by Republican state legislators in April.
content: A federal judge on Wednesday temporarily blocked Arkansas’s ban on gender-confirming treatments for transgender youths as a lawsuit over the first-in-the-nation state law advances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Koh
title: A Violinist on How to Empower Asian Musicians
description: Jennifer Koh, an acclaimed soloist, calls on classical music to make space for artists of Asian descent, who remain marginalized in the field.
content: I have not been surprised by the recent violence toward Asian Americans. I palpably remember being afraid when I was a child in Illinois, in the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Roy Hargrove and Mulgrew Miller’s Glorious Duets
description: Two performances by the trumpeter and pianist are collected on “In Harmony,” a new double album that takes on standards via a fresh lens.
content: On a snowy evening in January 2006, the trumpeter Roy Hargrove sped from Newark Airport to Merkin Hall, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, to play a rare duet concert with the esteemed pianist Mulgrew Miller. He got there just in time: There was no room for a rehearsal or even a proper soundcheck; they selected the set list while waiting in the wings, just before going onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: A couple face manslaughter charges after a wildfire started during a gender reveal party.
description: A firefighter died in September while battling the El Dorado Fire in San Bernardino County, Calif.
content: A Southern California couple are facing manslaughter charges in connection with a deadly wildfire last September that prosecutors say was sparked by a smoke bomb during a gender reveal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Agrees to Pay France £54 Million to Help Block Migrant Arrivals by Boat
description: The deal, which covers increased patrols by French security forces, comes amid an uptick in arrivals on the English coast, even though overall asylum applications in Britain are down this year.
content: LONDON — Britain has agreed to pay France 54 million pounds, about $73 million, to help clamp down on migrants crossing the English Channel by boat, despite the failure of similar attempts last year to significantly stem the number of arrivals taking that route.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Lifting Weights? Your Fat Cells Would Like to Have a Word
description: A cellular chat after your workout may explain in part why weight training burns fat.
content: We all know that lifting weights can build up our muscles. But by changing the inner workings of cells, weight training may also shrink fat, according to an enlightening new study of the molecular underpinnings of resistance exercise. The study, which involved mice and people, found that after weight training, muscles create and release little bubbles of genetic material that can flow to fat cells, jump-starting processes there related to fat burning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Tommie Smith Talks Protests and the Olympics
description: “I think within the next three weeks, we’re going to see some change in something. I don’t know from who. That’s why the future is so important.”
content: When the American sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos raised their fists on the medal stand at the Mexico City Games to protest the oppression of Black Americans, they gave voice to generations of the athletes eager to speak their minds, even as the International Olympic Committee and athletic federations try to curtail what they consider political demonstrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Lauren McCarthy
title: Life Expectancy, Opioids, Tokyo Games: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: The rising Delta variant.
content: The highly infectious Delta variant now accounts for an estimated 83 percent of new coronavirus cases in the U.S., up from 50 percent in early July. In some regions, the percentage is even higher — particularly where vaccination rates are low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: The National Labor Relations Board grants a reprieve to inflatable rats.
description: A symbol long used by union members to draw attention to suspect labor practices survives a legal challenge.
content: It turns out that inflatable rodents may be as unstoppable as their living, breathing cousins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger
title: In Deal With Germany, U.S. Drops Threat to Block Russian Gas Pipelines
description: The agreement infuriated both Republicans and Democrats in Congress, who accused the Biden administration of being soft on Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States has dropped its threat to block the Nord Stream 2 natural gas pipelines from Russia to Germany, officials said on Wednesday, formally setting aside a yearslong disagreement with Berlin over an energy deal that critics have warned would allow Moscow to starve Ukraine of transit fees that are crucial to Kyiv’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Pound Ridge, N.Y.: A Rural Alternative to Nearby Commuter Towns
description: Unlike its better-known neighbors, this Westchester town has no train station. It’s a ‘little bit more country,’ and residents are fine with that.
content: To see the changes happening in Pound Ridge, N.Y., a good place to start is Food Truck Fridays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Nightmare of Our Snooping Phones
description: A Catholic official’s resignation shows the real-world consequences of practices by America’s data-harvesting industries.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Calderone
title: My Quest to Become a Better Aunt
description: To develop a closer bond with my nephew, I asked the experts where to start.
content: When my sister called to tell me she was pregnant, my future with the kid instantly flashed before my eyes. Soon, I thought, we’d be wearing matching earth-toned jumpsuits in my Brooklyn studio apartment, baking cookies and butt-bumping to the latest LCD Soundsystem album.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Alzheimer Drug Approved Despite Doubts It Worked
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 21, 2021.
content: “To have a virtually unanimous vote against approval and then to have the F.D.A. turn around and approve — that’s never happened.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: World health officials call for urgent vaccine donations to stem Covid in Central America and the Caribbean.
description: Only 15 percent of people across Central America and the Caribbean have been fully vaccinated; in Honduras and Haiti, the figure is less than 1 percent.
content: Covid-19 cases are increasing in many Central American and Caribbean countries, officials from the World Health Organization warned on Wednesday as they called on richer nations to step up vaccine donations to a region where immunization rates remain perilously low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: A Covid adviser to the Pentagon, Max Rose, departs and reflects on his role.
description: Former Representative Max Rose, Democrat of New York, finished a six-month stint on Monday as a senior adviser on Covid-19 to the secretary of defense, Lloyd J. Austin III.
content: Former Representative Max Rose, Democrat of New York, finished a six-month stint on Monday as a senior adviser on Covid-19 to the secretary of defense, Lloyd J. Austin III.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Theater to Stream: ‘The Wolves,’ and More Archival Treasures
description: Productions from the National Theater in Britain, a project from Billy Porter and a Yiddish musical celebration are among the highlights.
content: Most Broadway productions disappear into that hazy province known as collective memory once they have closed. That’s the ephemeral beauty of theater, of course — yet wouldn’t it be great to be able to revisit some of your favorite stage moments, or share them with friends?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: A Rap Song Lays Bare Israel’s Jewish-Arab Fracture — and Goes Viral
description: A Jew and a Palestinian sling slurs at each other, giving voice to hidden prejudice with the aim of overcoming it.
content: BEIT YEHOSHUA, Israel — Uriya Rosenman grew up on Israeli military bases and served as an officer in an elite unit of the army. His father was a combat pilot. His grandfather led the paratroopers who captured the Western Wall from Jordan in 1967.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Sweden dominated the U.S. from start to finish.
description: The Americans had waited five years to avenge an Olympic loss to Sweden. They’ll have to keep waiting.
content: CHOFU, Japan — Five years. That is how long it had waited for this game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Joy Hassol, Kristie Ebi and Yaryna Serkez
title: America in 2090: The Impact of Extreme Heat, in Maps
description: Global warming will get worse unless we cut greenhouse gas emissions.
content: Yes, it is getting hotter. And while you might be able to escape the intensifying tropical storms, flooding or droughts by moving elsewhere, refuge from extreme heat is no longer easy to find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: The Anti-Vaccine Movement Is Much Bigger Than Facebook
description: The president blamed social media for vaccine misinformation. It’s not that simple.
content: Late last week President Biden achieved something I’d thought impossible: He got me to feel bad for Mark Zuckerberg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Liverpool Loses Its UNESCO World Heritage Status
description: A committee voted to strip the city in northwest England of its status because of concerns about redevelopment, most notably on its waterfront.
content: LONDON — Liverpool suffered the rare indignity on Wednesday of being removed from the list of UNESCO World Heritage sites after being granted the title 17 years ago, because of concerns about developments in the city, most significantly on its famous waterfront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld and Erin Woo
title: The Amazonification of Space Begins in Earnest
description: With the suborbital flights made by Jeff Bezos and Richard Branson this month, the privatization of the space industry has crossed the point of no return.
content: The anniversary of the Apollo moon landing marked one small step for space travel but a giant leap for space billionaires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden is in Ohio to promote his economic plan and appear in a televised town hall.
description: Mr. Biden toured a union training center and then headed to Cincinnati, where he will participate in a town hall airing at 8 p.m. Eastern.
content: President Biden flew to Cincinnati on Wednesday to promote his economic agenda and participate in a town hall aired on CNN, even as a bipartisan infrastructure agreement he brokered failed its first formal test in the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Beach Bums, Unite!
description: When it’s too hot to do anything else in New York City, that means it’s time to go to the beach.
content: True New Yorkers know that once the temperature soars past a certain point, there’s nothing to do but melt — and head to the water.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: Alan Ruiz’s architectural installations; New Red Order’s Indigenous provocations; and “Wish,” a group show exploring productive pleasures.
content: Even if you’ve been attending performances and exhibitions at the Kitchen for decades, it’s harder now than ever to locate this nondescript former industrial building on 19th Street: It’s been swallowed up in a maze of residential towers and luxury boutiques in Chelsea. Alan Ruiz’s blunt, spare but impressive exhibition “Container and Contained,” addresses some these problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Kennedy Center Taps Joni Mitchell and Berry Gordy for Awards
description: Bette Midler, Lorne Michaels and Justino Díaz will also receive tributes at a ceremony that is expected to look much more like it did before the pandemic.
content: The last Kennedy Center Honors aired on television less than two months ago, but on Wednesday, the institution announced a new batch of honorees, taking a step toward getting the program back on schedule after the upheaval of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Is the U.S. Economy Too Hot or Too Cold? Yes.
description: The economy is a riddle, but clearly it’s having a harder time rebooting itself than had seemed possible in the spring.t
content: Here’s a riddle: What is both too hot and too cold? The answer: the United States economy in the summer of 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Asians Are Represented in Classical Music. But Are They Seen?
description: The success of some artists of Asian descent obscures the fact that many face routine racism and discrimination.
content: As reports of anti-Asian hate crimes spread in the United States earlier this year, David Kim, a violist in the San Francisco Symphony, found himself despondent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: More Hospitals Are Requiring Workers to Get Covid Vaccines
description: With some health care workers still refusing to be immunized, medical centers around the country are requiring shots as cases climb once again.
content: More and more hospitals and major health systems are requiring employees to get the Covid-19 vaccine, citing rising caseloads fueled by the Delta variant and stubbornly low vaccination rates in their communities and even within their work force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Olmos and Christine Hauser
title: In rural Oregon, with fire on the horizon, ‘Everybody is freaking out.’
description: A family prepared to evacuate as the Bootleg Fire burned closer to their home and restaurant. In another town, T-shirts memorialized the nation’s largest blaze.
content: CHILOQUIN, Ore. — As firefighting crews stretched across central Oregon on Wednesday, battling to contain the nation’s largest wildfire, Tawan Murray sat in the parking lot of Chiloquin High School selling concert-style “Bootleg Wildfire 2021” T-shirts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annette Gordon-Reed
title: We Owe Haiti a Debt We Can’t Repay
description: Haitians carried out the first and only successful slave revolt in modern history, then repelled Napoleon's forces, making way for the Louisiana Purchase.
content: When assassins killed President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti on July 7, pushing the country to the brink of chaos, it may have struck many Americans as the latest in a string of political upheavals and destabilizing disasters in an unfortunate country with which the United States should have little to do. But the revelation that two of the suspects were American citizens was a reminder of the complicated history of our relations with Haiti — a needlessly tragic history, driven by self-interest and the politics of racism. As the United States now offers to help Haiti restore political order, it should be kept squarely in mind that Haiti is more than just a troubled neighbor. It is a nation whose revolutionary fight for freedom helped make the United States the country that it is today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: What You Need to Know About Germany’s National Election
description: Germans will vote on a new government in September, one without Angela Merkel, who will step down after 16 years in power.
content: BERLIN — Germans will vote on a new government on Sept. 26 and for the first time since 2005, Angela Merkel is not running. After nearly 16 years in power, Ms. Merkel, 67, will leave control of Europe’s largest economy to a new chancellor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: France’s Ideals Are a Harder Sell Among Diverse Youth
description: France has long sought to create a secular, colorblind republic. But a clash between a government minister and a youth conference shows how those values are being questioned by a new generation.
content: POITIERS, France — It was supposed to be a feel-good meeting meant to encourage civic-mindedness. More than a hundred teenagers from all over France had spent two days tackling the delicate topic of religion and discrimination. The government minister of youth, in her early 30s and herself a child of immigrants like many there, had come to listen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: Unearthing the Late Curiosities of Tennessee Williams
description: “Hilton Als Presents,” from New York Theater Workshop, features three of the playwright’s overlooked and often disparaged works.
content: Once mortals become immortal, it’s easy to forget how precariously they stumbled through life. That is certainly true of Tennessee Williams, who ensured his place in the pantheon of American playwriting with his early hits “The Glass Menagerie,” “A Streetcar Named Desire” and “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” but spent his last two decades — after “The Night of the Iguana,” in 1961 — in what Hilton Als calls “a kind of critical purgatory.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Keep It Simple (and Delicious)
description: Make a slow-cooker cherry tomato compote, and then use it on toast, in pasta or salads, or on top of anything grilled.
content: Good morning. I haven’t been writing much about no-recipe recipes these past few weeks, probably because so many of us are cooking no-recipe recipes all the time now, using the bounty of the season for freestyle tomato sandwiches, big bowls of steamed clams, piles of corn.  It’s hot and sticky where I stay, and sometimes the idea of following instructions step by step by step fills me with dread. I’d rather sear some scallops in butter, serve them with warm tortillas and a bowl of mango salsa without reading a word.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 21, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 21, 2021.
content: An article on Monday about the effects of climate change on winemaking in Napa Valley misidentified a site where tanker trucks take on treated wastewater for use in vineyards. It is a Napa Sanitation District facility, not a City of Napa sanitation department facility. (The Napa Sanitation District is run jointly by the city and the county, and covers the city as well as several adjacent county areas.)
source.name: The New York Times
